item.title: Criterion 2: Scholarly or creative achievement or research
item.description:
During my time as Associate Professor, I demonstrated scholarly or creative achievement or research in the following ways:

  • I was awarded funding by the American Eagle Foundation to analyze bald eagle telemetry data during sabbatical. Based on this work I published two articles in peer-reviewed journals and presented at national conferences.

  • I co-authored several articles published in peer-reviewed journals.

  • I presented at various national conferences.

  • I wrote an invited book review for The American Statistician.

  • I was awarded funding through the Innovation through COVID-19 application process and was invited to present a follow-up at Teach Together Minnesota.

  • I wrote an invited blog post for the Statistics Teaching and Learning Corner.

I was awarded funding by the American Eagle Foundation to analyze bald eagle telemetry data during sabbatical. Based on this work I published two papers in peer-reviewed journals and presented at national conferences.

Back to top

I was very grateful to receive a sabbatical during the academic year 2020-21. I enjoyed the break from teaching and the chance to engage in some very interesting applied research with excellent collaborators from around the country. My primary sabbatical research project was a major collaboration with Dr. Tricia Miller, Dr. Adam Duerr, and Missy Braham of Conservation Science Global; and Dr. Todd Katzner and Manuela Huso of U.S. Geological Survey. Over the last several years my collaborators had collected a large data set containing millions of GPS locations from 79 Bald Eagles, 30 free-flying birds captured in winter, 5 from rehabilitation facilities, and 44 tagged as nestlings. The resulting data are measured on very short intervals, as little as every 5 seconds, resulting in millions of geospatial and biological measurements. The below photos shows the same 7-week old bald eagle from above, after the telemetry device was attached and a close-up of the device.

The richness and extent of the data collected by these devices call for an automated process to classify and interpret the animal movement data. A defining feature of many previous methods developed for interpreting animal movement is that they were initially illustrated with telemetry data collected at relatively long time intervals. My role in this research was to apply statistical methods to that could be used to automate classifying risk to eagles from wind turbines using short-interval GPS telemetry data. To support my research efforts during sabbatical, Dr. Miller and I submitted a grant proposal to the American Eagle Foundation for $19,950.27. This was primarily to make up some of the income lost due to taking a sabbatical for an entire year. The grant was fully awarded.

  • Grant application packet

  • Grant award

The first part of my sabbatical research involved applying a framework for using K-means clustering to classify bird behavior using points from short time interval GPS tracks. My efforts on this part of the research resulted in an article on which I am first-author in Ecology and Evolution.

  • Bergen, S., Huso, M. M., Duerr, A. E., Braham, M. A., Katzner, T. E., Schmuecker, S., & Miller, T. A. (2022). Classifying behavior from short-interval biologging data: An example with GPS tracking of birds. Ecology and Evolution, 12, e08395. https://doi.org/10.1002/ece3.8395

The next step in my work involved classifying behavior using environmental features. The behaviors we were interested in classifying corresponded to different levels of risk from wind turbines. To carry out the classification I used boosted classification trees (BCTs) as implemented in the open source XGBoost package. XGBoost is a “big data” analysis tool that is computationally feasible even with billions of data observations, affording users a scalable and efficient implementation of BCTs with dramatic implications for model training. In this part of my research I applied BCT modeling with XGBoost to predict three categories of risk of bald eagle colliding with wind turbines in Iowa, and compared its predictive performance and computational time to other supervised learning methods.

I am the lead author on a second article summarizing this work in the highly-touted Methods in Ecology and Evolution.

  • Bergen, S., Huso, M. M., Duerr, A. E., Braham, M. A., Schmuecker, S., Miller, T. A., & Katzner, T. E. (2023). A review of supervised learning methods for classifying animal behavioural states from environmental features. Methods in Ecology and Evolution, 14, 189–202. https://doi.org/10.1111/2041-210X.14019

In addition the manuscripts, we submitted an abstract to the 2020 Wind Wildlife Research Meeting (that was held virtually Dec 1-4, 2020), which was accepted. This presentation centered mostly on the first part of my research, using K-means to cluster bald eagle flight. A video of the presentation is available by following the URL linked in the video image below.

I co-authored several articles published in or in preparation to submit to peer-reviewed journals.

Back to top

The following are journal articles published in peer-reviewed journals while Associate Professor, on which I am a contributing co-author. Most of these are projects in which I served as a consulting statistician:

  • Varela WL, Mundahl ND, Bergen S, Staples DF, Cochran-Biederman J, Weaver CR. Physical and Biological Stream Health in an Agricultural Watershed after 30+ Years of Targeted Conservation Practices. Water 15(3475). 2023. https://doi.org/10.3390/w15193475

  • Nelson HN, Treichel, AJ, Eggum EN , Martell MR, Kaiser AJ, Trudel AG, Gronseth JR, Maas ST, Bergen S, Hines JH. Individual neuronal subtypes control initial myelin sheath growth and stabilization. Neural Dev 15(12). 2020. https://doi.org/10.1186/s13064-020-00149-3

  • Frie KJ, Prochnow J, Meiers S, Fiedler T, Jones C, Bergen S. The implementation of a dedicated education unit in a public health setting. Public Health Nurs. 37: 789– 796. 2020. https://doi.org/10.1111/phn.12786

  • Goslee E, Chesak S, Forsyth DM, Foote J, Bergen S. Implementation of a Dedicated Education Unit Model for ADN Students in a Rural Primary Care Setting. Nurse Educator. Volume 45(2): 97-101. 2020. https://doi.org/10.1097/nne.0000000000000711

  • Fye HJ, Bergen S and Baltrinic ER. Exploring the Relationship Between School Counselors’ Perceived ASCA National Model Implementation, Supervision Satisfaction, and Burnout. Journal of Counseling & Development. 98: 53-62. 2020. https://doi.org/10.1

I presented at various national conferences.

Back to top

I have presented and led workshops at a variety of national conferences over the past two years, primarily on data visualization education.

  • Data visualization: principles and applications in R, Tableau, and Python. Workshop at SDSS 2019. Co-organizer: Todd Iverson. https://github.com/WSU-DataScience/SDSS19-dataviz-workshop

  • Teaching the Gestalt Principles to Help Undergraduate Students Design Effective Tables and Graphs. Contributed refereed presentation. SDSS 2020. https://bit.ly/3ikEFxv

  • Fundamentals of data visualization for education. Breakout session. USCOTS 2021. Co-leaders: Chris Malone and Jerzy Wiezcorek. https://github.com/DataVizEducation/USCOTS2021. Many participants mentioned the Gestalt principles (my portion of the breakout) in their evaluation of the breakout session, in response to “What was the most meaningful takeaway from this breakout session?”:

    • Human perception and Gestalt principles are very important to consider when you are thinking about how to communicate a message visually.

    • How our minds naturally "think" about groupings and interpret data via visualization - and how to communicate that to our students.

    • Gestalt principles were very eye opening for me!

    • Gestalt principles. I immediately started noticing it in media articles.

  • Ho to build and sustain a DSCI program. Topic contributed panel. JSM 2022. https://rb.gy/wk5zsm

  • What belongs together? Using elemental groupings and Gestalt principles to help students design more insightful data visualizations. Breakout session. USCOTS 2023. https://rb.gy/50218g

This latter presentation synthesized much of the conceptual framework I’ve been introducing in DSCI 310. One of the participants of this breakout enjoyed the session so much he invited me to present the material to faculty at his college as a Professional Development session:

Dr. Alicia Johnson from Macalester College invited me to review Displaying Time Series, Spatial, and Space-Time Data with R, 2nd Edition by Oscar Perpiñán Lamigueiro, for publication in The American Statistician. Dr. Johnson had this to say about my first review draft:

item.title: Criterion 3: Continuing preparation
item.description:
During my time as Associate Professor, I demonstrated continuing preparation in the following ways:

  • I took a class on the Python programming language.

  • I took the WeTeach course for effective online course design.

  • I read several books and online resources on data visualization design and best practices.

  • I sought out professional data visualizations as inspiration for DSCI 310 assignments.

I took a class on the Python programming language.

Back to top

During Fall 2020 I sat in on Dr. Todd Iverson’s course DSCI 330: Management of Unstructured Data. This course was taught entirely with the Python language, which gave me the chance to gain experience with this language. I grew a special appreciation for Python’s capability of managing strings. Below is a screenshot of one of my “homework” assignments:

I took the WeTeach course for effective online course design.

Back to top

I have taught online multiple times and wanted to learn more about effective online course design, especially given the growth of online teaching especially amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. To that end I completed the WeTeach course for effective online/blended course design and delivery in Summer 2020.

One of the best takeaways from this class for me was to create a discussion board for students to introduce themselves at the beginning of the semester. I have done this in all my online offerings since taking WeTeach. I think students appreciate this chance to get to know one another, as it helps reduce the isolation that can be an issue in online courses. It also gives students a way to find people to work with in homework groups if they do not already know someone in the course.

I read several books and online resources on data visualization design and best practices.

Back to top

I have explored many resources in preparation for teaching DSCI 310: Data visualization. As described in Criterion 1, I wanted to remake the way I taught DSCI 310 by focusing more on the concepts of quality data visualization. This included expanding my treatment of visual perception and designing for aesthetics and accessibility. The following books and online resources have proved hugely instrumental to my course design and thinking on data visualization in general and DSCI 310 specifically:

  • Show me the Numbers by Stephen Few

  • Storytelling with Data by Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic

  • Storytelling with Data: Let’s practice! By Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic

  • The Truthful Art by Alberto Cairo

  • The Grammar of Graphics by Leland Wilkinson

  • #MakeoverMonday by Andy Kriebel and Eva Murray

I sought out professional data visualizations as inspiration for DSCI 310 assignments.

Back to top

One way students improve as data visualizers is working to visualize a data set, then seeing a very high quality visual perspective on the same data. To that end, most of the design tasks I set my students in the data visualization course have a published visualization as its inspiration, which I show students after they have submitted their final drafts. Some examples are below.

item.title: Criterion 1: Teaching Effectiveness
item.description:
During my time as associate professor I taught the following courses:

  • FIN 335 – Forecasting methods

  • DSCI 210 – Data science

  • DSCI 310 – Data visualization

  • STAT 110 – Fundamentals of Statistics

  • STAT 303 – Introduction to Engineering Statistics

  • STAT 360 – Regression analysis

  • STAT 370 – Statistical consulting and communication

  • STAT 380 – Advanced statistical modeling

  • STAT 405 – Biostatistics

  • STAT 450 – Mathematical Statistics I

  • STAT 460 – Mathematical Statistics II

The following are ways in which I demonstrated Teaching Effectiveness during the past five years:

  • I developed high-quality activities and projects for DSCI 210: Data Science;

  • I developed rubrics to evaluate presentations, visual aids, written reports, and client meetings for STAT 370: Statistical Consulting and Communication;

  • I developed a successful and high-quality online learning experience for STAT 301: Statistical Thinking for Healthcare;

  • I improved and revitalized the content of and assignment structure in DSCI 310: Data visualization;

  • I created a suite of Colab notebooks, activities, and assignments for FIN 335: Forecasting;

  • I proposed and developed a brand new course – STAT 380: Advanced statistical modeling;

  • I created a suite of Colab notebooks, activities, and assignments for STAT 360: Regression analysis;

  • I continued a record of being an enthusiastic, helpful, and clear instructor in all my courses.

I developed high-quality activities and projects for DSCI 210: Data Science

Back to top

I taught DSCI 210 for my first time in Fall 2019 and Spring 2020. I inherited a quality curriculum outline with solid content from my colleague Dr. Todd Iverson. One area where I saw room for improvement was with in-class activities and class projects.

Activities

Building upon Dr. Iverson’s content, I developed a suite of near-daily activities to illustrate many of the concepts he had brought into the course. Many of these activities drew from data brought to the Statistical Consulting Center, which I had been directing for a couple years. Here are some examples.

Activity Example 1: WSU vehicle requests

The screenshot below shows data on requests for WSU vehicles:

{width=“6.5in” height=“3.0868055555555554in”}

Some of the tasks students had to do:

  • Clean “Destination City,” which was very messy as requesting parties could just type in their destination resulting in many variants of the same place (e.g. St. Paul; St paul; st paul; ST Paul St Paul/MPLS).

  • Pull off number of passengers, which is embedded in the Vehicle(s) field.

  • Compute average trip length for each vehicle, which requires differencing Departure from Return.

  • Find number of vehicles used for each trip, which required splitting the Vehicle(s) column when it contained multiple vehicles.

Activity Example 2: trout spawning data

The data below came from a consulting client, measuring redds (spawning nests) of stream trout.

From a data science perspective, there are many issues with this data that students had to grapple with including:

  • Highlighting indicating grouping status;

  • Different sections of streams contained in different spreadsheets;

  • Bold lines indicating 1000-yard segments;

  • One separate Excel file for each of 4 different years.

Activity Example 3: rape myth agreement

This data set also came from a consulting client working on a counsellor’s education master’s thesis. She wanted to compare rape myth belief as measured by the Illinois Rape Myth Acceptance Scale before and after a training on gender-based violence among student athletes. The raw data and the clean data are shown below:

Students needed to recode all of the Likert-scale items to come up with a single score for each student, then match the scores on the pre- and post-training data to develop the clean data set on the right.

Projects

Along with the in-class activities, I developed several in-class projects that required substantial application of the DSCI 210 content.

Project example 1: COVID-19 trends

This project required students to pull data from a Github repository, clean it, and visualize it. This was a final project which required a substantial amount of coding, cleaning, and visualizing with R:

Project example 2: MUDAC 2020

This final project build on MUDAC 2020, which focused on understanding whether various motions made during civil rights trials could predict the outcome of the trial. Some of the questions students had to answer with this data involved whether filing rates differed by district, and how the prevalence and frequency of motions impacted likelihood of cases being settled or taken to trial. Students had to use association rules, a recently learned technique, to analyze the former.

Feedback

Student feedback on the activities and project was very positive. Below are student responses to the statement “The in-class activities helped me to understand the course material,” combined across both Fall 2019 and Spring 2020 semesters:

Additionally, students referenced the activities and projects when asked “The thing I liked MOST about the course was…”

In class group activities

Using real world data and tools such as Open Refine

All the in class examples and activities made sure I understood the material.

In-class activity because that way you could practice the topics just discussed in class which will help to know the content better.

Small sections, with lots of in-class exercises to reinforce concepts.

Making the COVID graphs in R was really cool, I liked using real data to get my results.

I enjoyed the topic and the practice with the different applications.

I developed rubrics to evaluate presentations, visual aids, written reports, and client meetings for STAT 370: Statistical Consulting and Communication.

Back to top

As associate professor, I taught STAT 370 four times (Fall 2019, 2021, 2022, 2023). This course requires students to write frequent reports and design PowerPoints to accompany their oral presentations. There was no consistent way of evaluating these so I developed two rubrics that I felt were successful in distinguishing between various qualities of student reports and presentation slides.

As the number of clients we served in the course continued to increase, I also wanted a way to help students understand the components of a leading a quality statistical consulting meeting. Accordingly, brand new in Fall 2023, I developed a “client meeting” rubric that I used to hold students accountable for preparing and leading professional, helpful meetings with clients. Each student was evaluated with this rubric four times in Fall 2023:

30 points total Excellent (10 points) Poor (1 point)
Professionalism Student demonstrated high professionalism throughout and had a pleasant demeanor. Nonverbal cues were entirely professional. Student appeared disinterested in the client, perhaps sounding condescending and irritated. The student’s nonverbal cues were highly unprofessional.
Preparation Student was very well-prepared. Student demonstrated they had reviewed all relevant information before the meeting and had prepared questions regarding the material, if applicable. Student clearly had not reviewed the materials the client provided before the meeting. Student seemed disoriented during the meeting.
Information gathering Student asked pertinent questions and fully gathered all information needed to advise the client on next steps. The student made sure they understood the client’s research questions, data, etc. Student had a difficult time asking questions and ended the meeting before fully understanding the client’s research questions, data, etc.

The following are comments from clients served by the students taking STAT 370, as recorded by a Consulting Feedback Survey I sent the clients following the conclusion of their collaboration with our class, which I offer to demonstrate the high standard students were held to by these rubrics:

Thank you for providing this experience for your students and this resource for campus!

Then as we started writing out the manuscript, we kept going back to the statistician to ask for further information. I am truly grateful that the student was really patient with us.

We had a great experience! The class was extremely helpful.

I improved and revitalized the content of and assignment structure in DSCI 310: Data visualization

Back to top

I taught DSCI 310 the first three times it was ever offered at Winona State, each fall 2015-2017. I took a few years off and revisited the course in Fall 2021. I have taught the course as Associate professor three times: Fall 2021, 22, and 23. The content and structure of the course is drastically different now than it was the first three times I taught it. There are two major ways the course is improved: increased conceptual focus, and regular peer review.

Increased conceptual focus

The first three times I taught the course, the entirety of my notes were screenshots of Tableau (a visualization software). The content was essentially, “How to use Tableau.” An example from my Fall 2017 notes:

All of the software “how to” has now been pushed entirely into video tutorials for the students to watch, and in its place is a much more comprehensive set of PowerPoints on principles of data visualization and guidelines for making good graphs. These notes focus much more on helping students [design more effective graphs], and contains content I have aggregated myself across a variety of sources.

My most up-to-date notes include:

  • Grammar of graphics

  • Visual principles for comparing quantities

  • Principles for visualizing groups

  • Design considerations

    • Color

    • Clutter

    • Focusing audience attention with preattentive attributes

My first few activities in DSCI 310 are completely devoid of software, emphasizing design and principles over technology:

  • Grammar of graphics activity

  • Grouping principles activity

  • Decluttering and focusing activity

With this redesign, learning Tableau is a medium for achieving the learning objective of creating effective graphs goal rather than the goal itself, which results in a much more satisfactory and quality class.

Regular peer review

Learning how to be an effective critic of your own work is key to improving as a data visualizer. I can critique a student’s work until I’m blue in the face, but to really take the next step a student needs to be able to look discerningly at their own work. How can I, as an instructor, help my students be better critics? To this end, beginning in Fall 2022, I implemented a peer review system for every major design task I assigned students:

  • Each student is required to submit a first draft of their assignment to CrowdGrader, a website that facilitates anonymous peer review.

  • Each student is assigned a small number (5-6) of their classmates’ first drafts. Students evaluate each draft using a rubric I provide, and are also required to provide specific, actionable feedback on the draft.

  • After receiving their peer feedback, students are allowed to incorporate it into a final draft they submit to me for a final grade.

Below is an example of the peer review process.

Not only is the feedback received by each student valuable in creating an improved final draft, but the student who submits the first draft must also provide feedback for 5-6 peer visualizations, thus being exposed to a variety of different visual approaches to the same data set while sharpening their critical eye.

For each design assignment, I evaluate not only the quality of the final drafts, but the quality of feedback each student provides their peers during the feedback process. This ensures students provide high-quality feedback and are practicing being specific in ways to improve each visualization they review.

In course evaluations, I asked students two statements regarding the peer review process. The responses of 40 students across 2 semesters (Fall 2022 and 2023) are summarized in the table below.

Strongly agree Agree Disagree Strongly disagree
Evaluating peers' visualizations in CrowdGrader helped me improve my ability to effectively critique visualizations. 24 13 3 0
Receiving feedback from my peers via CrowdGrader helped me improve my visualizations. 15 16 9 0

Students also commented on the aspects of evaluating and receiving peer feedback they found most helpful:

Training myself to critique vizzes has been really helpful because I am now more critical of my own vizzes

I liked being able to see things other could improve on because that in turn gave me things to be aware of on my vizzes

It helped to give me more ideas and also see what other people were making mistakes on so I could go back and look at mine more clearly.

The descriptions were always very helpful in understanding what other people see when they look at my viz

Evaluating helped me realize what are good things in a visual so then I could make mine better

The peer reviews helped me see problems with my visualizations that I didn’t see.

The constant loop of feedback, critique, and ideas that it provided is very nice!

The first comment really nails why I think this is such an important part of their learning process: learning how to be more critical of their own work is crucial to becoming an effective communicator via data visualization.
